resources.string: What should I do to prevent another heart attack?

"Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) also knows as coronary angioplasty." "Its purpose is to open up blocked coronary arteries caused by coronary artery disease and restore blood flow to the heart muscle.\n\n"
"It is an invasive procedure involving X-rays taking, which use a special thin tubing" "instrument with an attached deflated balloon and is threaded up to the coronary" "arteries. The cardiologist will inflate the balloon to widen blocked artery area where" "blood flow to the heart muscle has been reduced or cut off. Sometimes, it is combined" "with the implantation of a stent to help to keep the artery open and decrease the risk of" "another blockage." "The fundamentals of light, surface, and movement are key to conveying how objects move, " "interact, and exist in space and in relation to each other. Realistic lighting shows " "seams, divides space, and indicates moving parts."

"Your heart is a muscle that pumps blood to your body, delivering oxygen and" "nutrients to all the cells. Your heart needs its own supply of oxygen and nutrient. " "Coronary arteries play an important role in supplying blood to your heart muscles."

"Your heart’s arteries can become blocked or narrowed by a buildup of cholesterol" "(atheroma), cells, or other substances (plaque). This build up process is called" "atherosclerosis. Atheroma will reduce blood flow to your heart and causes chest pain" "(angina). If blood clot formed or get worse where it completely block blood flow, it" "can cause a heart attack (myocardial infarction)."
"You will need to come be in the hospital a day earlier before the procedure. Blood" "test and electrocardiogram (ECG) will be conducted."
"Tell the doctor or nurse if you are hypersensitive to any contrast dye, medication," "iodine, seafood or shellfish used as X-ray contrast during PCI."
"Inform doctor if you are pregnant or think you may be pregnant because you will" "be exposed to radiation during PCI."
"Inform doctor if you are taking any over the counter medication, vitamins, herbs" "and supplements."
"You will be asked not to eat or drink for at least six hours before PCI to prevent" "nausea or vomiting, because painkiller may be given during procedure."

"You will be asked to remove jewelry that you are wearing and to shave in the area" "of your body and where the catheter will be inserted. Catheters are usually put in" "through your wrist or at your groin site."
"You will be asked to empty your bladder prior to the procedure."
"An intravenous (IV) line will be inserted into a vein for administration of" "painkillers or sedatives."

"You will be taken to the cardiac catheterization laboratory and asked to lie on an" "examination table. You will be connect to monitor to monitor your ECG, heart rate," "blood pressure, breathing rate and oxygen level."
"The site to perform the procedure will be cleaned."
"During the procedure, you will be awake and alert. Doctor will numbs a spot on your wrist or groin before the starting of the procedure."

"A small incision will be make in the skin of your wrist or groin over an artery" "where your pulse can be felt. A needle is inserted into the artery followed by a wire. A" "small tube called s sheath is inserted into the artery to keep it open.\n\n" "*Tell the doctor if you feel pain during incision."

"Doctor will insert a small catheter (a fine, flexible, hollow tube) into the artery at the sheath.\n\n" "*You may be asked to take a deep breath and hold it for a few seconds to allow" "the catheter to pass through some point in your artery."

"There is an X-ray monitor screen in the procedure room. Special fluid (radio-opaque dye)" "will be injected through the catheter so arteries show up well on the X-ray.

" "*You might feel a hot, flushing sensation, a salty or metallic taste in the mouth," "or brief headache when dye passes through.

" "*Rarely, you may feel some chest discomfort, nausea or urge to urinate as the" "fluid goes in.

" "*If you feel any breathing difficulties, sweating, numbness, itching, nausea or" "vomiting, chills, or heart palpitation, tell the doctor."
"X-rays are taken as the fluid goes through the artery. Doctor can see exactly where" "the narrowing of the artery, and how severe they are."

"By watching on the screen, catheter with a thin, expandable balloon on the end is" "passed to the blockage.\n\n" "*You shouldn’t feel anything as the catheter moves through the heart artery, but" "you may feel an occasional missed or extra heartbeat."

"The balloon is inflated. It pushes plaque to the side and stretches the artery open, so" "that blood can flow more easily.

" "*You may feel some chest pain when the balloon is inflated as the artery will be" "completely blocked. However, this is normal and is nothing to worry about.

" "*But if you notice continued discomfort or pain, such as chest pain, neck or jaw" "pain, back pain, arm pain, shortness of breath, or breathing difficulty, tell your" "doctor immediately."

"If needed, a stent (collapsed wire mesh tube) mounted on a special balloon, is" "moved over the wire to the blocked area. As the balloon inflated, it opens the stent" "against the artery walls. The stent is locked in this position and is placed inside your artery to keep the artery open."

"When the procedure finished, the cardiologist will check that your artery is wide" "enough to allow blood to flow through by monitoring a small amount of contrast dye" "as it flows through the artery."
"The balloon and catheters are taken out. Now the artery has been opened, and your" "heart will get the blood it needs."

"A stent is a short, wire-mesh scaffold that is spring-like which expands and locks into" "place to help keep your artery open. It stays in your heart artery after procedure.

" "There are two main types of stent:

" "- Bare metal (uncoated) stent
" "- Drug-eluting stent (coated with medication that reduces the risk of the artery becoming blocked again)

" "If you have a stent, you will need to take certain medication to help reduce the risk of blood clots forming around the stent. These include Aspirin, Clopidogrel or Prasugrel."

"After PCI

" "- If your PCI is done through wrist, the sheath will be removed and you will go back" "to ward with a TR band around the wound to stop bleeding.

" "*Tell the doctor or nurse if you feel numbness or pain on your arm.

"

"- If PCI is done through groin area, PCI sheath will be left in the femoral artery for 6" "hours. It will be stitched to your skin and cover with bandage.

" "*Do not bend the leg where the sheath was inserted.

"

"Bed rest may vary from 2 to 6 hours depending on your condition.

" "- If PCI is performed from the wrist artery, but you should not bend your arm and" "should rest on bed for 2 hours. The wrist compression device will be removed from" "your arm after 2 hours if there is no bleeding seen on your arm.

" "- If it is done through groin area, you would need to lie quietly on your back for 6" "hours. PCI sheath on your groin will be removed by your doctor. Nurse or doctor will" "apply direct pressure for 15 minutes or longer to the place where the catheter was" "inserted to ensure that there is no internal bleeding."

"Doctor or nurses will check for signs of bleeding or chest discomfort. Your blood" "pressure, heart rate, breathing rate and oxygenation level will be monitored.

" "*You need to inform the nurse if you feel any pressure in your chest or shortness" "of breath during your hospital stay after procedure.

" "*Cover your PCI site gently if you need to cough or sneeze to prevent bleeding."
"Move slowly when getting up from bed to avoid any dizziness from the long period of bed rest."
"You will need to drink plenty of fluids. This will help your kidneys to flush out the contrast dye from your body."
"You will need to stay in the hospital for a night to rest or longer if required depending on your situation."

"It is normal to have a small bruise or lump at the site.

" "1. Do not scrub the site.

" "2. For the first 2 days: do not stoop or squat. When you cough, sneeze or move your" "bowels, hold your hand over the puncture site and press gently.

" "3. Do not lift more than 4.5kg for at least 3 to 5 days.

" "4. If you start bleeding from the site, lie down flat and press firmly on the site. Call for an ambulance."

"It is normal to have soreness at the punctured site and mild tingling in your hand for up to 3 days.

" "1. For 2 days, do not use your hand or arm to support your weight (rising from a" "chair) or bend your wrist.

" "2. For 2 days, do not lift more than 2kg or exercise your arm.

" "3. If you start bleeding from the site, sit down and press firmly on the site with your" "fingers for 10 minutes. If the bleeding stops, sit still and keep your wrist straight for 2" "hours. If bleeding does not stop, go to a hospital."

"1. When you have chills or a fever greater than 38 degree Celsius.

" "2. New swelling or the bruising becomes widespread at the PCI site.

" "3. Site become hard and painful."
"4. Bleeding from wound that does not stop or restarts after applying pressure for 10 minutes. \n\n" "5. Arm or leg changes colour or becomes numb or cool to touch"
What should I do to prevent another heart attack?

"Stop smoking because smoking causes:

" "- Reduction of oxygen to the heart muscle.
" "- Heart-rhythm problem.
" "- Harms to the artery walls.
" "- Increased in heart rate and blood pressure.
" "- Lowering of “good” cholesterol (HDL)."

"Eat a healthy diet

" "- Eat at least five portions of a variety of fruit and vegetables a day.

" "- Cut down on saturated fats. These are found mostly in foods from animal" "sources such as organ meat, fatty meat, and high-fat dairy products such as" "butter, ghee, cheese and cream.

" "- Eat low-fat protein such as cooked dried beans and peas, fish, poultry and lean red meats.

" "- Replace saturated fat with small amount of unsaturated fats such as olive," "rapeseed, sunflower oils, as well as oily fish and some nuts and seeds.

" "- Eat less salt. Possible not to add salt when you are cooking or eating. Use" "alternatives such as herbs and spices to flavor your food. Look at the food" "labels to help you choose food that are lower in salt."

"Watch your weight\n\n" "- Reduce weight will help to lower "bad" cholesterol (LDL), lower" "triglycerides, raise "good" cholesterol (HDL), help control high blood" "pressure, control or prevent diabetes, reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke."

"Watch your cholesterol level\n\n" "- Keep your cholesterol level low as it is the main reason causing" "atherosclerosis. Doctor will prescribed a medication call statin to help lower" "your cholesterol level and protect your heart."

"Watch your blood pressure\n\n" "- Monitor blood pressure and have a lifestyle changes to keep blood pressure" "under control: regular physical activity, keeping to a healthy weight, cutting" "down on salt and alcohol, and taking prescribed medication."

"Keep physically active\n\n" "- For post PCI, do not try to push yourself too hard at first in activity. Build up" "your activity gradually. Follow the cardiac rehabilitation team advice, try to" "build up at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity in a week."

"Take your medication as prescribed\n\n" "- Doctor will give medication that help reduce the risk of having a heart attack" "and slow down the progression of your coronary heart disease. It is important" "to take the medication as advised and do not stop without first checking with your doctor."

"Reduce stress\n\n" "- Long periods of stress are common factors in high blood pressure, high" "cholesterol and heart disease. Plan time to relax, learn relaxation techniques," "and set goals to relieve your stress."
